captions.text:
So you mean you're
in math class,

yet again, because they make
you go every single day.

And you're learning
about, I don't know,
the sums of infinite series.

That's a high
school topic, right?

Which is odd, because
it's a cool topic.

But they somehow manage
to ruin it anyway.

So I guess that's why they
allow infinite serieses
in the curriculum.

So, in a quite understandable
need for distraction,

you're doodling
and thinking more

about what the plural
of series should
be than about the topic at hand.

Serieses, serises,
seriesen, seri?

Or is it that the singular
should be changed?
One serie, or seris, or serum?

Just like the singular
of sheep should be shoop.

But the whole concept
of things like 1/2

plus 1/4 plus 1/8 plus
1/16, and so on approaches 1

is useful if, say, you want to
draw a line of elephants, each

holding the tail
of the next one.

Normal elephant, young
elephant, baby elephant,

dog-sized elephant,
puppy-sized elephant,

all the way down to
Mr. Tusks, and beyond.

Which is at least
a tiny bit awesome

because you can get an infinite
number of elephants in a line

and still have it fit across
a single notebook page.

But there's questions,
like what if you started

with a camel, which, being
smaller than an elephant,

only goes across a
third of the page.

How big should the
next camel be in order

to properly approach
the end of the page?

Certainly you could calculate
an answer to this question,

and it's cool that
that's possible.

But I'm not really interested
in doing calculations.
So we'll come back to camels.
Here's a fractal.

You start with these
circles in a circle,

and then keep drawing
the biggest circle that
fits in the spaces between.

This is called an
Apollonian Gasket.

And you can choose a different
starting set of circles,
and it still works nicely.

It's well known in
some circles because it

has some very interesting
properties involving

the relative curvature of
the circles, which is neat,
and all.

But it also looks cool and
suggests an awesome doodle
game.
Step 1, draw any shape.

Step 2, draw the biggest circle
you can within this shape.

Step 3, draw the biggest circle
you can in the space left.
Step 4, see step 3.

As long as there is space left
over after the first circle,

meaning don't start
with a circle,

this method turns any
shape into a fractal.
You can do this with triangles.
You can do this with stars.
And don't forget to embellish.

You can do this with elephants,
or snakes, or a profile of one
of your friends.
I choose Abraham Lincoln.
Awesome.

OK, but what about other
shapes besides circles?

For example, equilateral
triangles, say,

filling this other triangle,
which works because the filler

triangles are the opposite
orientation to the outside

triangles, and
orientation matters.

This yields our friend,
Sierpinski's triangle,

which, by the way, you can also
make out of Abraham Lincoln.

But triangles seem to work
beautifully in this case.
But that's a special case.

And the problem
with triangles is

that they don't
always fit snugly.

For example, with
this blobby shape,

the biggest equilateral triangle
has this lonely hanging corner.

And sure, you don't have
to let that stop you,
and it's a fun doodle game.

But I think it lacks some of
the beauty of the circle game.

Or what if you could change
the orientation of the triangle
to get the biggest possible one?

What if you didn't have
to keep it equilateral?

Well, for polygonal
shapes, the game

runs out pretty quickly,
so that's no good.

But in curvy, complicated
shapes, the process
itself becomes difficult.

How do you find the
biggest triangle?

It's not always obvious
which triangle has more area,

especially when you're starting
shape is not very well defined.

This is an interesting
sort of question

because there is
a correct answer,

but if you were going to
write a computer program that

filled a given shape
with another shape,

following even the simpler
version of the rules,

you might need to learn
some computational geometry.

And certainly, we can
move beyond triangles
to squares, or even elephants.

But the circle is
great because it's just
so fantastically round.

Oh, just a quick little
side doodle challenge.

A circle can be defined
by three points.

So draw three, arbitrary
points, and then try

and find the circle
they belong to.

So one of the things that
intrigues me about the circle

game is that, whenever you have
one of these sorts of corners,

you know there's going to be
an infinite number of circles
heading down into it.

Thing is, for every one
of those infinite circles,

you create a few
more little corners

that are going to need an
infinite number of circles.

And for every one
of those, and so on.

You just get an
incredible number

of circles breeding
more circles.

And you can see just how
dense infinity can be.

Though the astounding thing
is that this kind of infinity

is still the smallest,
countable kind of infinity.

And there are kinds of infinity
that are just mind bogglingly
infiniter.

But wait, here's an
interesting thing.

If you call this distance 1
arbitrary length unit, then

this distance plus
this, dot, dot, dot,

is an infinite series
that approaches 1.

And this is another, different,
series that still approaches 1.
And here's another, and another.

And as long as the outside
shape is well defined,
so will the series be.

But if you want the simple kind
of series, where each circle's

diameter is a certain
percentage of the one before it,
you get straight lines.

Which makes sense
if you know how

the slope of a straight
line is defined.

This is good because it suggests
a wonderful, mathematical,

and doodle-able way to
solve our camel problem,
with no calculations necessary.

If instead of camels,
we had circles,

we could make the
right infinite series

just by drawing an angle
that ends where the page does
and filling it up.

Replace circles with
camels and, voila,

infinite Saharan caravan
fading into the distance.
No numbers necessary.

Well, I have an infinite
amount of information

I'd like to share with
you in this last sentence.
[VOICE SPEEDS UP]

title: Doodling in Math Class: Infinity Elephants

Imagine this: You are clapping your hands, but you only reduce the distant 
that your hands travel by half each time you bring them closer. If you do

wow.﻿

comments.text:
So I was just wondering (I'm a freshman in high school) what would happen 
if a circle had an infinite diameter? Or does that just simply, not work?﻿
comments.author: Octodog

comments.text:
+Simone Noli I think i'm right, but may be mistaken. In complex analysis we 
saw lines as circles with infinite radius and I think it should work the 
same way in a real plane.
Assume we have a circle radius r which touches the origin. it has the 
equation:
(x-r)^2 + y^2 = r^2

let’s see what happens to it as r->inf

first rewrite the equation a little. 

(x-r)^2 + y^2 = r^2
x^2 + y^2 + r^2 - 2xr = r^2
(x^2 + y^2)/r -2x = 0

now let r->inf

we get the line x=0, which is the y-axis. This is a line.

comments.author: Chris Palmer

comments.text:
I'd never thought that it was possible for an elephant to be drawn an 
infinite number of times on a piece of paper. I've always in a way 
understood the concept of infinity, but this video really gave me a visual 
in my head to see when I hear the word infinity. I was confused about what 
fractals and Apollonian Gaskets were, but upon further research, I learned 
that fractals were just a type of pattern that repeat an infinite number of 
times. An Apollonian Gasket is then a type of fractal that is composed of 
triplets of circles. This video definitely led me to do some more research, 
and it inspired me to make my doodles more interesting. ﻿

comments.text:
Listen to my logic, if the elephants started off half the length of the 
page, then the next was half a half (quarter) then the next was half again

comments.author: CoolAsFinnBro

comments.text:
If we scale every elephant up by a factor of 2, we end up with the first 
one taking up an entire page, the second taking up half a page, the third 
taking up a quarter of a page, and so on. What initial size we pick isn't 
all that's relevant; the ratio between the sizes of consecutive 
camels/elephants/whatever is independent and also relevant. The question 
she posed roughly boiled down to what ratio should we should pick to fill 
up the page.

+Kevin Kelbie +Kevin Kelbie Im no genius, but I assume that it's because 
the circles are getting infinitly smaller, and therfore the room doesnt 
really matter as long as they fit in the originial confine of the area. 
They aren't expanding or becoming infinitly big, but are compressing. But 
then again that's just my assumption, aslo it's very difficult to 
comprehend infinity, and some would even call it incomprihensible to full 
extent.

Imagine this: You are going to clap your hands, but you only reduce the 
distant that your hands travel by half each time you bring them closer. If 
you do this, your distance will be reduced to 50% of the original distance, 
then 25%, then 12,5%, 6,25%, etc. but they will never actually touch.﻿

comments.author: stephanjacob17

comments.text:
No there's is only one type of camel per se, it depends where you draw the 
(arbitrary) line, if dromedaries are not camels then there is only the 'two 
humped camel'. But if you look at the extant camelid species as camels then 
you have to include these two plus the South American llamas and a few 
others (which most wouldn't call camels and have no humps)
comments.author: patrickneilkilloran

comments.text:
Eh, it's not that she's asking because she doesn't know. She's asking why 
English is stupid enough to have both the plural and singular forms for the 
word "series" (and a number of other words) be exactly the same, which you 
would've understood if you weren't so quick to assume Americans are stupid.
Please, don't go around calling entire countries stupid. In America, that 
is called STEREOTYPING and is frowned upon by society in general.
Don't post your ignorance on the internet.

comments.author: Izzy Fosty

comments.text:
This video definitely takes a new spin on doodling in math class! It took a 
concept, the sums of infinite series, and transformed it into art. The cute 
little doodles were very relatable as often boredom causes students to 
begin drawing mini masterpieces. The video was able to take the Apollonian 
Gasket and apply it to infinite series. I had never heard of an Apollonian 
Gasket until this video and the concept is neat, and one I will probably 
try. Circles had always been unique especially in geometry and 
trigonometry, but the idea that you can create an awesome doodle out of 
their properties is fascinating, especially as the example of using 
triangles fails. However, the triangle example also fits the question of 
the camel. Thus the idea becomes related to doodling circles with the 
Apollonian Gasket. My only confusion is in the concept of infinity. Its 
hard to grasp the idea that you can draw infinite amount of circles, 
triangles, camels, etc. Overall though, this video was amazing and I 
enjoyed watching it. ﻿
